# Data Structures IV

<span class="lead"> </span>

A traversal is an operation in which each node of a data structure such as a tree is “visited”. We’ll examine two types of traversals - Depth First Traversal (DFT) and Breadth First Traversal (BFT).

**At the end of this module, you should be able to:**

- complete a Depth First Traversal and a Breadth First Traversal of a tree

#### Pro Tip

A witty saying proves nothing.

Voltaire

## <a href="#prepare" id="prepare" class="anchor"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Prepare

Review each preclass resource before class.

## <a href="#learn" id="learn" class="anchor"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Learn

#### Learn to complete a Depth First Traversal and a Breadth First Traversal of a tree

Traversals are a difficult but important concept that can be used to solve a number of problems - both real world, and those found in coding tests or interviews. The techniques used to traverse a tree are similar to, but a little less complicated than those for a graph. This is the first stepping stone to understanding some of the most challenging problems in computer science.

##### Overview

Trees can be thought of as being similar to a few different types of data structures. They’re similar to linked lists, except with multiple `next` nodes. They are also a special type of graph. We’ll learn more about the details of graphs in another lesson, but the great thing is that this means that we can use a number of techniques on both graphs and trees. In particular, we can use both a DFT and a BFT to “crawl” over the tree from node to node. This is useful for many tasks - search, printing, callbacks, and a number of other things. We’ll use our Binary Search Tree (BST) for this exercise, but these techniques will work on many other types of trees and graphs.

Before we start, a quick note. The terms `search` and `traversal` are often used interchangeably. A number of resources, including the Wikipedia page for both items, describe them in such a way that can make them sound the same. However, there is a difference.

A `search` is completed when the target of the search is found. A `traversal` is completed when _every_ node has been explored.

A `Depth First Traversal (DFT)` is one that continues traveling forward on each branch until a dead end is reached. The search then retreats to the first unexplored branch and follows the next unexplored path until that one too reaches a dead end. This continues until all nodes have been visited. Think of it like being in a maze and always turning right at each intersection. We can do a DFT recursively or iteratively. The iterative approach makes use of `stack`.

A `Breadth First Traversal (BFT)` takes the opposite strategy. We explore layer by layer, slowly moving outward from the starting point. At each node, we add every node we discover to the list of nodes to explore, then explore them in the order in which we encounter them. For this, we use a `queue`. This means we’ll jump around a bit - the next node we visit might not be directly connected to the one we are on.

##### Follow Along

Follow along as we conduct each type of search on the whiteboard and use our lessons learned to build pseudo-code for our coding problems.

##### Challenge

On your own, complete several types of traversals.

## <a href="#review" id="review" class="anchor"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Review

### Class Recordings

You can use class recordings to help you master the material.

- **[Data Structures IV for CSPT12 w/Elissa Thomas](https://youtu.be/IwdRARCyLjI)**

  A review of recursion. Learn to complete a depth first traversal of a tree (DFS). Learn to complete a breath first traversal of a tree (BFS). Why BFS and DFS is used.

- [All previous recordings](/archive/CS/module/recHdwPne4Xt3A7lk)

### Demonstrate Mastery

To demonstrate mastery of this module, you need to complete and pass a code review on each of the following:

- Objective challenge:

  On your own, complete several types of traversals.
